instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ON_OFF: What is SMC_ON_OFF? SMC_ONOFF tells the computer that the power button has been pressed..
definitions.PP3V3_SO: What is PP3V3_SO? PP3V3_SO is a typo of PP3V3_S0.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi I checked al the cpu prerequisites

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>=3.32v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>=3.24v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>=3.24v
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL>=.489mv
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=2.7v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>=.468mv
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>=3.45v

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
Pin 1 <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>= 3.3v
Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3v
Pin 3 <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2_R</SIGNAL>=1.2v
Pin 4 <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> = .9v
Pin 13 <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.42v
Pin 12 <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL>= .390mv

I replaced <RESISTOR>R7822</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7821</CAPACITOR> that where torn off and <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> had burnt traces pins 3,4 ran a trace to pin2 “<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>” from <RESISTOR>R2889</RESISTOR> pin 1 from pin 2 of <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
thank you for your help

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I’m sorry my apologies <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=3.3v
I’m thinking it’s the <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> or y2805 but I’d like your input first
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
PIn 14 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_T29</SIGNAL>= 2.49v
Pin 11 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SO</SIGNAL> =1.8V
Pin 6 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_ENET</SIGNAL>=3.3v
Pp3v3 seems a little on the low side and I checked them multiple times.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_T29</SIGNAL> is to low; check <CHIP>U3890</CHIP>.
Removing <CHIP>U3880</CHIP> should disable T29 block.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok I will trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF</SIGNAL> and check <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>. I had I to a S0 state with 1/4 spin and now it’s back in short :/  It has no gpu so that’s not a problem.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok so when I checked <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> does pulse. Since someone removed j6700 I figured I’d check <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> and it was shorting the 5v rail I changed it and now I’m booting fine. Fans spin It chimes But has no audio In OS X. the same issues as before but in reverse as Homer Simpson would say “d’oh“ :( I replaced j6700 and I found 3 Through hole traces were Burned. ( J6700 : pin 9, GND ‘I tied in to ground‘, pin 8 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SO</SIGNAL> ‘Also repaired’, pin 7 <SIGNAL>AUD_SPDIF_OUT</SIGNAL> ‘which I tried grounding and it did nothing’ So I left it without connecting it to anything’)Head phones do work but built in speakers don’t. How can I disable spdif Out. I have no red light inside port. :( I need like a jumper solution I’ve removed a few resistors and what I believe are filter capacitors still have gotten it right yet. <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> ? I don’t have the whole machine Todo a software disable
I’m sorry I took this weekend to work on the bottom of the barrel
Thank you for your help

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Removing <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> should disable SPDIF.

macOS recognizes speakers?
What says when you connect/disconnet headphones?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Mac OS doesn’t recognize internal speakers. When I connect headphones it says headphoneS in setting/sound (input/output area) let me ask you the link between <SIGNAL>AUD_SPDIF_OUT</SIGNAL> and the component by <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> is broken will this in anyway affect it from not switching to internal speakers ?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check connections for pins 1 & 2 of J6700.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>820_2915</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It’s all good thanks for you help :) I’m on to the next board now

This can help other people in the future.
